Relative risk is calculated by dividing the incidence rate of a disease in an exposed group by the incidence rate of the disease in an unexposed group. In this case, the exposed group is the 1,000 patients who have been exposed to carriers of the virus, and the unexposed group is the control group of 1,000 patients who have not been exposed to carriers of the virus. 

The incidence rate of the disease in the exposed group is 500/1000 = 0.5. The incidence rate of the disease in the unexposed group is 5/1000 = 0.005. 

The relative risk of contracting the virus if exposed is (0.5 / (1 - 0.5)) / (0.005 / (1 - 0.005)) = [0.5 / 0.5] / [0.005 / 0.995] = 100.
